rsbNotes.title: Ps 7
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 7 A lament and psalm of refuge by an innocent person beset by enemies. As one falsely accused of murder could find sanctuary in the house of God and appeal his case to God’s judgment, so the psalmist commits his case to God. His protestations of innocence refer to specific charges and are not a claim to be sinless. See Ps. 11; 17; 26; 27; 31; 71.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 7:2
rsbNotes.text: 7:2 like a lion. Though not found in Israel today, lions were plentiful there in ancient times. The lion often symbolized power, cruelty, and ruthlessness (Is. 5:29; Nah. 2:11, 12).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 7:5
rsbNotes.text: 7:5 let the enemy. He is not afraid to invoke a curse on himself, since he knows he is innocent.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 7:6
rsbNotes.text: 7:6 Arise. See 3:7 note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 7:8
rsbNotes.text: 7:8 judge. There is a judicial setting in this psalm of refuge. God must judge between the psalmist and his opponents.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 7:14–15
rsbNotes.text: 7:14, 15 conceives evil . . . makes a pit. These terms express the conviction that a sinner reaps what he sows. Sin brings its own retribution.
